questions.text: Which of the following complement products are considered anaphylatoxins?
questions.solution:
Complement system must know facts:

  • An important soluble component of the innate immune system, is a series of plasma enzymes, regulatory proteins, and proteins that are activated in a cascading fashion, resulting in cell lysis.

Four pathways of the complement system

  1. Classic activation pathway activated by antigen/ antibody immune complexes
  2. MBL (a serum collectin) activation pathway activated by microbes with terminal mannose groups
  3. Alternative activation pathway activated by microbes or tumor cells,
  4. The terminal pathway that is common to the first three pathways and leads to the membrane attack complex that lyses cells.

C3a and C5a are considered anaphylatoxins.

questions.text: Recurrent infection by Neisseria Bacteria is seen in which of the complement deficiency?
questions.solution:
Complement molecules and their roles:

  • C1Q, C3, C4: The cleavage products of complement components facilitate microbe or damaged cell clearance
  • C3a and C5a: promote activation and enhancement of inflammation (anaphylatoxins)
  • Membrane attack complex (C5-C9) promote microbe or opsonized cell lysis (membrane attack complex).
  • Deficiencies of early complement components C1, C4, or C2 can be associated with autoimmune disorders (e.g. Systemic lupus Erythematosus) or with encapsulated bacterial infections like Streptococcus pneumoniae. Deficiencies of late complement components (C5-C9) are associated with increased Neisseria infections.

questions.text: All of the following are considered subtypes of CD4 T cell except?
questions.solution:
Must know facts about immune cells:

  • Cells of monocyte-macrophage include tissue macrophages (and certain of their specialized forms) are found in lymph node, spleen, bone marrow, perivascular connective tissue, serous cavities such as the peritoneum, pleura, skin connective tissue, lung (alveolar macrophages), liver (Kupffer cells), bone (osteoclasts), central nervous system (microglia cells), and synovium (type A lining cells). Monocyte-macrophage system acts as first line of defence against infecting microbes.
  • Dendritic cells are most potent antigen presenting cells in the body. They are the most potent producers of type 1 interferon (like IFN-alpha)

questions.text: Which of the following Immune cell/cells is the principal effector cell of Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC)?
questions.solution:
EFFECTOR CELLS OF INNATE IMMUNITY

  1. Monocyte-macrophage- first line of defence against invading bacteria.
  2. Dendritic cells - most potent antigen presenting cell and producer of type I interferon.
  3. Innate lymphoid cells include innate lymphoid cells type 1/2/3, lymphocyte tissue inducer and NK cells
    1. NK cells-principal effector cells for Antibody dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC). This is not MHC-restricted. This is responsible for elimination of malignant cells and virus infected cells.
    2. Lymphocyte tissue inducer cell (LTi)-critical for formation of lymph nodes and payer patches.
  4. Neutrophils, eosinophils and basophils

Mode of functioning of NK cells: Non-MHC mediated and non-antibody dependent. NK cells use inhibitory receptors to gauge the absence of constitutively expressed self-molecules on susceptible target cells. In particular, NK cells express MHC class I-specific receptors and 'lose' inhibitory signals when encountering MHC class I-deficient hematopoietic cells. This is depicted below.

questions.text: Which of the following is primary effector for cell mediated immunity?
questions.solution:
• Immune system has two major arms-Innate and adaptive.
  • Adaptive has two arms-cellular and humoral.
  • This question is about cellular arm which means Cellular arm of adaptive immunity. Therefore answer is T cells.
  • Had question been effector cell of immune system then it will also include NK cell (which is one of the cells of innate lymphoid cells)

Important facts about T-cells:

  • T-cells are the primary effectors of cell- mediated immunity, with subsets of T cells maturing into CD8+ cytotoxic T cells capable of lysis of virus-infected or foreign cells (short-lived effector T cells) and CD4+ T cells capable of T-cell help for CD8+ T-cell and B-cell development. CD-4 Tcells are primary regulatory cells of T and B cells.
  • Two populations of long-lived memory T cells are triggered by infections: effector memory and central memory T cells. Effector memory T cells reside in nonlymphoid organs and respond rapidly to repeated pathogenic infections with cytokine production and cytotoxic functions to kill virus-infected cells. Central memory T cells home to lymphoid organs where they replenish long- and short-lived and effector memory T cells as needed.

choices.text: Foreign antigens are presented by antigen presenting cells in combination with class I MHC molecules.
Endogenous antigens are presented by antigen presenting cells in combination with class II MHC molecules.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about antigen recognition by T cell receptor of T cell receptor (alpha-beta type)?
questions.solution:
There are 2 very important points regarding antigen presentation to T Cells of alpha-beta variety:

Only protein antigens are recognised by t cells and t cells recognise protein antigens only when they are presented in combination with MHC molecules this particular property is c called as MHC restriction.

  • Exogenous antigens are presented in combination with Class 2 MHC molecules by antigen presenting cells.
  • Endogenous antigens are presented in combination with class I MHC molecules by antigen presenting cells.
  • C8 T cells interact with class I MHC molecules and CD 4 t cells interact with Class II MHC molecules.

So exogenous antigen-presented with MHC II molecules to CD-4 T cells and endogenous antigens are presented in combination with class I MHC molecules to CD8 t cells.

Unlike T cells, which recognize only processed peptide fragments of conventional antigens embedded in the notches of MHC class I and class II antigens of APCs, B cells are capable of recognizing and proliferating to whole unprocessed native antigens via antigen binding to B-cell surface Ig (sIg) receptors.

Lipid antigens: can be presented in combination with CD1 molecule to gamma delta type of T cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is a Co stimulatory molecule during antigen presentation by antigen presenting cell capital (APC) to T cells?
questions.solution:
The antigen presentation by APC to T cells requires at least 2 signals

  1. First signal is provided by the antigen in combination with MHC molecule interacting with CD 4 or CD 8 cell
  2. Second signal is provided by a set of molecules called as Co stimulatory or Co inhibitory molecules.

Concept of super antigen: super antigens bind directly to the lateral portion of T-cell receptor beta subunit leading to activation of large fraction of t cells in the circulation. Usually the interaction between antigen presenting cell and T-cells is specific hence very small fraction of Tcells Which are specific for the antigen are only activated.

questions.text: Somatic hypermutation is seen in which of the following immune cells of the body?
questions.solution:
Somatic hypermutation - is a mechanism, that occurs in germinal centres of lymph nodes, whereby point mutations in rearranged H- and L-genes give rise to mutants Ig molecules, some of which bind antigen better than the original sIg molecules.

Somatic hypermutation, therefore, is a process whereby memory B cells in peripheral lymph organs have the best binding or the highest-affinity antibodies. This overall process of generating the best antibodies is called affinity maturation of antibody.

Salient differences between B and T cells:

questions.text: Which of the following Immunoglobulin molecule is marker for mature B cells?
questions.solution:
Important facts about Human immunoglobulin molecule:

  • All immunoglobulins have the basic structure of two heavy and two light chains. Immunoglobulin isotype (i.e., G, M, A, D, E) is determined by the type of Ig heavy chain present.
  • Light chains have one variable (VL) and one constant (CL) unit; heavy chains have one variable unit (VH) and three or four constant (CH) units, depending on isotype.
  • Constant regions are involved in biologic functions of Ig molecules. e.g. The CH2 domain of IgG and the CH4 units of IgM are involved with the binding of the C1q portion of C1 during complement activation.
  • Variable regions (VL and VH) constitute the antibody-binding (Fab) region of the molecule. Within the VL and VH regions are hypervariable regions (extreme sequence variability) that constitute the antigen-binding site unique to each Ig molecule.
  • The idiotype is defined as the specific region of the Fab portion of the Ig molecule to which antigen binds. Antibodies against the idiotype portion of an antibody molecule are called anti-idiotype antibodies.

questions.text: The predominant antibody during secondary immune response is?
questions.solution:
• IgM antibody is predominant during primary immune response but during second exposure to same antigen IgG antibodies are predominant.
  • J chain is present in IgM and IgA molecules as these exist as pentamer and dimer commonly.
  • IgA in secretions (tears, saliva, nasal secretions, gastrointestinal tract fluid, and human milk) is in the form of secretory IgA (sIgA), a polymer consisting of two IgA monomers, a joining molecule, again termed the J chain, and a glycoprotein called the secretory protein. Of the two IgA subclasses, IgA1 is primarily found in serum, whereas IgA2 is more prevalent in secretions. IgA fixes complement via the alternative complement pathway and has potent antiviral activity in humans by prevention of virus binding to respiratory and gastrointestinal epithelial cells.

questions.text: Which of the following subtype of CD4 T cell play an important role in killing of intracellular bacteria like mycobacterium tuberculosis?
questions.solution: Important subtypes of CD4 T cells:

questions.text: Which of the following is the principal cytokine produced by T regulatory cells?
questions.solution:
Important facts about T regulatory cells:

  • Control immune responses are CD4+ and CD8+ T regulatory cells. These cells express the α chain of the IL-2 receptor (CD25), produce IL-10, and suppress both T- and B-cell responses.
  • T regulatory cells (Tregs) are induced by immature DCs and play key roles in maintaining tolerance to self-antigens. Loss of Treg cells is the cause of organ-specific autoimmune disease in mice such as autoimmune thyroiditis, adrenalitis, and oophoritis.

questions.text: The following T cells have been used for treatment of malignant conditions and refractory autoimmune condition. These T cells consist of single-chain variable fragment (SCVF), with intracellular signalling domains from activating co-stimulatory molecules (from endogenous TCRs, CD28, or 4-1BB) that allow for retargeting of T cells to antigens on malignant cells. These cells are known as?
questions.solution:
Chimeric Antigen Receptor T cells:

Bispecific monoclonal antibody: Newly engineered, bispecific monoclonal antibodies are artificial proteins that can bind simultaneously to the tumor surface and to an activating receptor of effector cells using two distinct epitopes. Through this means bispecific antibodies directly recruit effector cells to the tumor cell and activate them to induce anti-tumor responses.

questions.text: All of the following molecules are present on T cells except?
All of the following are Primary Immune deficiency caused due to T-lymphocyte dysfunction except?
Which of the following diagnostic tests are used for the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease?
Presence of Howell-jolly body in the peripheral blood is seen in which of the primary immunodeficiency syndrome?

choices.text: Impaired phagocytic killing of microorganism by neutrophils and Macrophages.
Defective negative selection of T-Lymphocytes in thymus.
Defect in Toll like receptor signalling
Deficiency of immunoglobulins leading to defective opsonisation.

questions.text: Chronic granulomatous disease is a primary immunodeficiency caused by?
questions.solution:
Chronic Granulomatous disease:

  • Impaired phagocytic killing of microorganisms by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • X-linked recessive inheritance (most common) versus autosomal inheritance in the remaining 30%.
  • Recurrent skin infections (such as folliculitis) are common and can prompt an early diagnosis of CGD. The infectious agents are typically catalase-positive bacteria (such as Staphylococcus aureus and Serratia marcescens)
  • CGD is caused by defective production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the phagolysosome membrane following phagocytosis of microorganisms.
  • As its name suggests, CGD is also a granulomatous disease. Macrophage-rich granulomas can often arise in the liver, spleen, and other organs.
  • Treatment: prophylactic usage of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole and HSCT in rare cases. Prophylactic antifungals may also be considered. Due to an increase in reported successes, HSCT is now an established curative approach for CGD.

questions.text: Guthrie card test is used for newborn screening of which of the following primary immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
T-cell quantification of receptor excision circle by using Guthrie card test is used for newborn screening of severe combined immunodeficiency.

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency:

  • Caused by profound block in T-cell development
  • The most frequent SCID phenotype results from a deficiency in either the common γ chain (γc) receptor (that is shared by several cytokine receptors (the IL-2, -4, -7, -9, -15, and -21 receptors) or Jak-associated kinase (JAK) 3 that binds to the cytoplasmic portion of the γc chain receptor
  • The former form of SCID (γc deficiency) has an X-linked inheritance mode (The most common pattern of inheritance).
  • Other defects leading to SCID include:
    1. Adenosine deaminase (ADA deficiency): Apart from immunodeficiency its deficiency can also cause bone dysplasia with abnormal costochondral junctions and metaphysis (found in 50% of cases) and neurologic defects.
    2. DEFECTIVE REARRANGEMENTS OF T- AND B-CELL RECEPTORS
    3. Reticular dysgenesis

Treatment: Today, HSCT(Hematopoetic Stemcell Transplantation) provides a very high curative potential for SCID patients Gene therapy has been found to be successful for cases of X-linked SCID (γc deficiency) and SCID caused by an ADA deficiency.

questions.text: CHARGE syndrome is associated with immunodeficiency secondary to?
questions.solution:
• CHARGE (coloboma of the eye, heart anomaly, choanal atresia, retardation, genital, and ear anomalies) syndrome (CHD7 deficiency) is a less frequent cause of impaired thymus development.
  • Di-George Syndrome: In ~1% of such cases, the thymus is completely absent, leading to virtually no mature T cells. Diagnosis (using immunofluorescence in situ hybridization) is based on the identification of a hemizygous deletion in the long arm of chromosome 22.

questions.text: An young 4 male presents with progressive cerebellar ataxia. Examination reveals dilated blood vessels over sclera. His mother also gives history of recurrent infection since birth. There is history of death of sibling in early childhood. Which of the following is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The Diagnosis is Ataxia-telangiectasia. Presence of ataxia, telangiectasia, recurrent infection and history of sibling death suggest underlying immunodeficiency. Primary immunodeficiency is commonly seen in Ataxia telangiectasia.
  • DNA fragility syndromes associated with immunodeficiency:
    • Ataxia-Telangiectasia syndrome: The autosomal recessive disorder ataxia-telangiectasia (AT) causes B-cell defects (low IgA, IgG2 deficiency, and low antibody production), which often require immunoglobulin replacement. AT is associated with a progressive T-cell immunodeficiency. The hallmark features of AT are telangiectasia and cerebellar ataxia. Diagnosis is based on a cytogenetic analysis showing excessive chromosomal rearrangements (mostly affecting chromosomes 7 and 14) in lymphocytes. AT is caused by a mutation in the gene encoding the ATM protein
    • Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS) results from chromosome instability. NBS is characterized by a severe T- and B-cell combined immune deficiency with autosomal recessive inheritance. Individuals with NBS exhibit microcephaly and a bird-like face but have neither ataxia nor telangiectasia. The risk of malignancies is very high. NBS results from a deficiency in nibrin

choices.text: Increased size of platelet on peripheral smear

questions.text: Incorrect about Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome?
questions.solution:
Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome:

  • WAS is a complex, recessive, X-linked disease caused by mutations in the WASP gene that affect not only T lymphocytes but also the other lymphocyte subsets, dendritic cells, and platelets.
  • WAS is typically characterized by the following clinical manifestations: recurrent bacterial infections, eczema, and bleeding caused by thrombocytopenia. Another possible consequence of WAS is lymphoma.
  • Predisposition to autoimmune disorders is in part related to defective regulatory T cells.
  • Thrombocytopenia can be severe .
  • A typical feature is reduced-sized platelets on a blood smear.
  • Diagnosis is based on intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASp) expression in blood cells.
  • Treatment: Prophylactic antibiotics, immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation, and careful topical treatment of eczema are indicated. Although splenectomy improves platelet count in a majority of cases, this intervention is associated with a significant risk of infection (both before and after HSCT). Allogeneic HSCT is curative, with good results overall.

choices.text: Antibody response following vaccination for the conjugated pneumococcal polysaccharide.
B cell phenotype determination-switched and non-switched memory B cell.

questions.text: All of the following is used to make diagnosis of B-cell related primary immune deficiency except?
questions.solution:
• Conjugated vaccines like conjugated pneumococcal vaccines act through help of T cells so can't be used for estimation of B-cell deficiency. Rather unconjugated vaccine response is used for diagnosis of B cell deficiency.
  • Serum Ig levels
  • B-cell phenotype determination in switched μ-δ-CD27+ and nonswitched memory B cells (μ+δ+ CD27+). In agammaglobulinemic patients, examination of bone marrow B-cell precursors.

Other important facts about B-cell primary immunodeficiency

  • Most common presentation is invasive, pyogenic bacterial infections as well as recurrent sinus and pulmonary infections (mostly caused by S. pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis)
  • Symptoms are not present in initial 6 months after birth due to presence of maternal antibodies.
  • BTK gene mutation is most common cause of agammaglobulinemia.
  • Treatment of agammaglobulinemia or hypogammaglobulinemia is periodic replacement of IVIG.

questions.text: Which of the following is most common Primary Immunodeficiency worldwide?
questions.solution: IgA deficiency is the most common primary Immunodeficiency worldwide.

questions.text: Defective Fas mediated apoptosis by lymphocytes results in which of the following primary immunodeficiency?
questions.solution:
• Autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS) is characterized by non-malignant T and B lymphoproliferation causing splenomegaly and enlarged lymph nodes;
  • 70% of patients also display autoimmune manifestations such as autoimmune cytopenias, Guillain-Barree syndrome, uveitis, and hepatitis.
  • A hallmark of ALPS is the presence of CD4-CD8- TCRαβ+ T cells (2-50%) in the blood of affected individuals.
  • The syndrome is caused by a defect in Fas-mediated apoptosis of lymphocytes, which can thus accumulate and mediate autoimmunity. Furthermore, ALPS can lead to malignancies.

Option B and C: Immunodeficiency syndromes (increased risk of hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis )with partial albinism: Three conditions combine HLH and abnormal pigmentation, where hair examination can help in the diagnosis: Chediak-Higashi syndrome, Griscelli syndrome, and Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome type II. Chediak-Higashi syndrome is also characterized by the presence of giant lysosomes within leukocytes.

Option D: IPEX syndrome-immune dysregulation polyendocrinopathy enteropathy X-linked syndrome (IPEX), characterized by a widespread inflammatory enteropathy, food intolerance, skin rashes, autoimmune cytopenias, and diabetes. The syndrome is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the gene encoding the transcription factor FOXP3. In most cases of IPEX, CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells are absent from the blood.
